course.subject: MATH
course.name: Advanced Probability Theory I
course.description: Probability spaces and random variables, distribution functions, expectations and moments, independence, convergence concepts, law of large numbers and random series.

reviews.author: Captuna
reviews.title: What a great teaching and nice course!
reviews.comment_content:
Basically follow the first three chapters from the book Probability: Theory and Examples by Durret
(Free download: https://services.math.duke.edu/~rtd/PTE/PTE5_011119.pdf),
Including:
1. Measure Theory (From basic to product measure)
2. Laws of Large Numbers
3. Central Limit Theorems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Personally, Durret's book is not friendly to me but Prof. Bao's teachings are extremely great! He explained the content very well with many examples. Sometimes the textbook use R^d as examples, which can be quite abstract at first glance while Prof. Bao gave us some examples in R1 or R2 instead, which is much intuitive and readable than the textbook.

If you didn't take the honor probability course (MATH 2431) or a measure theoretic probability course in UG, you'll find in this course that what you learnt in UG are almost "blowing water".
For example, in UG course, you learnt "distribution function" but you may not know what's the actual meaning of "distribution", then this course gonna tell you distribution is a push-forward measure.

If your measure theory is not very good, or even if you didn't take an UG course on it, you can also tackle this course because Prof. Bao will spend almost a month to teach you Measure Theory (From basic to product measure). Some minor/long proofs may skimmed, but the proofs of some key lemma/thm are included during lessons, such as BCT, MCT and LDCT.
reviews.comment_grading: Although grades are not that important if you were PG student and Prof. Bao agrees with this, the grading is very friendly. I answer all the questions and got an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Only one take home final exam, not difficult and we have nearly one week to finish it.

reviews.author: 神月 godmoon
reviews.title: Challenging but fruitful PG lesson
reviews.comment_content:
Very different from what I expected

Content:
Textbook: Theory and Examples by Durret, a typical PG textbook for probability courses. (Free download: https://services.math.duke.edu/~rtd/PTE/PTE5_011119.pdf),
Including:
1. Measure Theory (From basic to product measure)
2. Laws of Large Numbers
3. Central Limit Theorems

As a senior UG student at HKUST, I found that the content is very different from what I learned in Math 2421 and other advanced probability or statistics course. So I recommend you should first go and check the content in the textbook. There is basically no calculation, but rather we use analysis to tackle the problem. In this course, we would focus more on the proof l. However, knowledge in advanced probability course definitely help.

I think chapter 1 is highly related to the set/measure and chapter 3 is more likely the probability part. If you are not similar to analysis (like me), you would suffer a lot in the early stage. You will find that the notation in chapter 1, such as sigma field, production space, vector, and Borell set is very hard to understand. But “don’t give up”, you would find the content very easy after you get used to it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think Professor Bao is a very good lecturer. This teaching is very clear. I think it is very smart to spend half of the time on the first part of the content since it is very important, but basic knowledge in this course. Professor did care for students with very few analysis backgrounds/ students from other majors.

On top of Professor Bao’s teaching, I think you can also refer to Professor Chen Kani’s lecture notes. The lecture notes are very well organized and it also provides a lot of good exercise with solutions. You can find the related resources on coursehero and studocu.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Assignment
70% Final Exam

The grading scheme is very different from the previous semesters. Professor may want students not taking the advantage of the online exam and changing it to a face-to-face exam too.

The assignment answer can be found on the Internet. Most of them come from the textbook exercise. But I suggest you try to do it before checking the answers as the questions in the final are very similar to those in the assignments.

Grade: A-

No score was released. I did not do well in the assignments, but I think I did a good job on the final exam and received a good grade in the end.

However, I can feel that all students in the class are very smart and diligent. So I cannot say it is a lenient grading. You can expect the grading is competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light.

3 assignments with a total of around 25 questions.
You should complete each assignment in 4~10 hours if you can follow the teaching progress.

The exam consists of 8 questions. The difficulty is similar to, if not, easier than the assignment questions.

reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.title: Real analysis in finite-measure space
reviews.comment_content:
1. Official textbook: P.T.E., which is famously applied in many universities for measure-theoretic probability theory. The first three chapters are covered.

2. Other references:
-> Probability and random process, Grimmett (official textbook in MATH2431)
-> Probability and measure, Billingsley
-> Real analysis, Folland (For detailed reference of measure-theoretic knowledge)
-> Mathematical Statistics, Shao (A good question bank)

3. Course content:

========Part One: Measure theory======

TL;DR: A crash course in real analysis. Say, you will learn Lebesgue measure without knowing the explicit definition. Some concepts are carefully discussed, but some proofs of important theorems are omitted, like Fubini theorem, Caratheodory extension theorem, Rieman-Lebesgue theorem (for equivalence in compact intervals). About one month is used for this part.

i. Three core components of probability space:
-> Sample space (Set of experimental outcomes)
-> Sigma-algebra (Subset of sample space, "stable" under countable union, intersection and complement)
-> Probability measure (A (continuous) mapping that maps each event in sigma algebra to a probability)
ii. Set limit (limsup and liminf)
iii. Abstract measure space (General definition of measure space; Lebesgue measure is introduced as example)
iv. Borel sigma algebra (smallest sigma algebra containing all open subsets)
v. Stieljes measure function (Determines unique measure in Borel measure space; Theoretical foundation of distribution function)
vi. Random variables and three aspects:
-> Aspect One: Mapping from sample space to some real number
-> Aspect Two: Measurable function (Inverse image maps Borel sets to Borel sets)
-> Aspect Three: Mapping from measure space to measure space (with pushforward measure - Distribution function)
vii. Lebesgue integral. Two purposes  for introducing L. integral in modern probability:
-> Unify "discrete" and "continuous random variables
-> Derive criterion for exchange order of limit and integral (in pointwise sense, or even weaker)
-> Construction steps: Simple function, bounded functions, nonegative functions, real-valued functions
ix. Inequalities: Jensen, Holder, Markov...
x. Convergence modes: ("almost everywhere", "in L^p") implies "in measure" implies "in distribution"
xi. Theorems for exchanging limit and integral (B.C.T., Fatou, M.C.T., L.D.C.T.)
xii. Product measure (For introducing "independent events" and Fubini theorem)
xiii. Independence, in event, random variable and sigma-algebra aspects
xiv. Implication of convergence modes in measure space, and counterexamples.

=========Part Two: Laws of large number========

TL;DR: Besides of the original version of law of large number, many variants and corresponding applications are discussed. It turns out that the variants are more applicable than the original one...

xv. Many variants of weak law of large number
-> Variant 1: Uncorrelated, second moment uniformly bounded
-> Variant 2: Triangular array, second moment under controlled, no requirement for independence
-> Variant 3: Triangular array for truncated r.v.
-> Variant 4: Requires xP(|X_n| > x) \to 0 only
-> Original WLLN: Required existence of first moment only
xvi. Borel-Cantelli lemma (Sum of probability, and probability of infinite often)
xvii. Sub-subsequence trick (equivalence of "in measure" and "a.s." for subsubsequence
xviii. S.L.L.N.
xix. Applications for the weak/strong law and its variants:
-> Berstein polynomial (Uniform approximation of continuous function)
-> Borel Geometric concentration (High-dimensional "uniform" measure is not "uniform", but concentrated on some hyperplane)
-> Coupon-collection problem (Asymptotic time for collection all types of cards)
-> Occupancy problem (Asymptotic behavior again)
-> St. Petersberg paradox (A good application for the necessity of "truncation")
-> Infinite monkey problem (A monkey can recover Shakespear's piece infinitely often)
-> Renewal process (Faulty of lightbulb)
-> Glimenko-Cantelli lemma (Uniform convergence of empirical distribution)
-> Borel zero-one law, Kolmogorov zero-one law
-> Random power series

=========Part Three: Central limit theorem========

TL;DR: Different from previous part, this part focuses on the convergence behavior in distribution.

xx. Alternative definition of "in distribution/weak convergence" via continuous bounded functions (similar to weak* convergence in functional analysis?)
xxi. Method of characteristic function (A special choice of the "continuous bounded function")
xxii. Theoretical justification for the usefulness of characteristic function:
-> Relation fo order of Taylor expansion of c.f., and the existence of moment of original r.v.
-> (Fourier) Inversion theorem
-> Equivalence of convergence of d.f., and convergence of c.f.
xxiii. Proof of CLT and WLLN via method of c.f.
xxiv. Lindeberg-Feller CLT (Triangular array variant; More useful usually)

=========Part Four: Non-examinable content, continuation of Part Three=========

TL;DR: Advanced content. Some results like stable law and infinite divisible distribution has the role of "indication" instead of "application".

-> Construction of Poisson process
-> Stable law
-> Infinite divisible distribution
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. Sophisticated. The instructor is able to teach related content fast, without any hesitation and looking at any reference. He can even recite the corresponding code of theorem in the official textbook.

2. Friendly. The instructor usually gives patience for after-class questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Unlike previous policy, this time 30% from homework and 70% from final exam are counted for grades.

Update: Super lenient grade! Although I am not outstanding in MATH2431 and
I am not confident with some questions in the exam (in this course), I can still get a decent grade in this course! Also, given that I took the exam on 16 Dec and I get back the grade 3 days after, the professor has high working efficiency!
reviews.comment_workload: Because of the change in "grading part", there is no chill policy like take home exam. For tackling exams, since questions from different textbooks (like the textbooks I listed out in previous part), you should explore those questions in textbook and know how to finish them using appropriate variants.

reviews.author: Arkux
reviews.title: Nice and Rewarding Journey
reviews.comment_content:
Reference book: "Probability: Theory and Examples" by Rick Durrett, the book can also be found online.

The course roughly follows Chapter 1-3 of Durrett, and the actual content being covered are subject to Prof BAO's selection. But anyway, the lectures themselves will be quite self-contained.

For instance, one key thing that you will learn is to determine when does a sequence of random variables S_n (after proper centering and scaling) converge weakly / almost surely / in probability, and what are the limits. You might have seen some results when S_n is the sample mean of a given i.i.d. RV sequence X_i, e.g. you may have learnt WLLN, SLLN and CLT in some applied probability course. But this course is going to extend them into more general settings, say, what results we can conclude when X_i are not independent, when X_i are not identically distributed, when X_i does not have first moment, when the quantity of interest S_n is no longer the "average", and so on.

If you have taken MATH2431, you will find that it has many overlaps with this course, but this course will completely omit computational stuffs and focus even more on the proofs and extensions on the limiting theorems (e.g. the techniques of truncation and sparsification). On the other hand, it is worth mentioning that this course is way way way different from an applied probability course (e.g. MATH2421 or its exclusions), as this course will be based on a rigorous measure-theoretic probability framework, in which many concepts and proof techniques in real analysis will appear very often almost surely. If you are UG and have not taken any honor MATH course, I would recommend you to enroll in this course only if you are willing to tackle MATH3033-related stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very clear and well-organized. Instead of providing lecture notes in advance, Prof BAO starts everything from scratch during the class. Moreover, he is not only writing things up line-by-line, but he also gives comprehensive explanations on what's happening behind. For example, besides giving a direct proof to a theorem, he also try to tell us the intuition behind the theorem / proof, and the mindset that we should take away from the proof. These mindsets are really something useful but might not be that easy to gain if we read the textbook directly. I personally think this is the best way to teach MATH courses.

Since lecture notes are (intentionally) NOT provided, you should find your own way to address this. As I found myself hard to catch up the content at the same time when I copy Prof BAO's writing in class, what I did is just to listen and take photos of the whiteboard during the class, fill in my own notes after class using the photos and the RVC recordings, and consult the textbook iff further details are needed.

Although it is a little bit inconvenient without lecture notes, it is harmless to the overall learning experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% - Homeworks*3, one for each chapter
70% - Final Exam, f2f and close-book

Note that the grading scheme is different from the last few years, in which the grades are solely determined by a take-home final. Prof BAO said he realized some students want to take advantage from that lenient scheme, so he change it in order to 勸退 some of us. However, it is not a problem for those who are really willing to follow and learn from the course.

It turns out that the grading is good! Although I did not take MATH2431 before (and I got a B+ in MATH3033), I can still get an A here.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair. But if you don't have a solid analysis background, you should definitely work a bit harder.

If you manage your time properly, you will have pretty enough time to finish the homeworks. If you wish to write up your own notes, you can expect around 4~7 (A4-sized) pages for every 3-hour lecture.

reviews.author: distance
reviews.comment_content: The course contains most important things in probability with appropriate examples. The logic is similar to the famous textbook (Probability of Durrett).
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is so smooth and you can feel the instructor's deep understanding from it. The explaination is much clearer than that in my UG course. The only drawback is that sometimes the teaching is a little fast and you don't have time to take notes. As long as you can follow him, you can learn a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good. Although there is a final exam this year, most students get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There are three homework (30%) and a fina (70%)l, and the homework can help you prepare for the final exam.

reviews.author: Squidgy
reviews.title: I am BZG no.1 fan
reviews.comment_content:
Follow others.
Durrett's " Probability: Theory & Examples " is very useful. The homework questions are mostly from it and it is also good for self-learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof explained the concept very good. However, with the large amount of content needs to be covered, he did not give us time to digest in the class and kept teaching. It was actually quite hard for me to follow his lecture. I looked at the lecture recordings afterward in my own pace and it was good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good but still maybe not.
All of the grades (hws and exam) are not revealed and then the letter grade just appeared. I don't know how well the others performed but I thought I performed only fair (or poor) on the exam but still get a good grade. Thank you BZG.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 assignments, probably take one or two days for each one.
Notice that the exam is closed book and no cheat sheet is allowed, so probably you need to memorize a lot of theories and examples before the exam...

reviews.author: Ravix
reviews.comment_content:
Probability spaces and random variables, distribution functions, expectations and moments, independence, convergence concepts, law of large numbers and random series.

On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. Develop a rigorous mathematical framework to analyze randomness based on measure theory.
2. Derive probability inequality as a useful tool for mathematical analysis.
3. Demonstrate various forms of laws of large numbers and large deviation and their applications.
4. Establish the central limit theorem and present their applications.
5. Apply random walk theory to actuarial analysis.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Bao's teaching is extremely great! He can explain a thing very clearly and smoothly.
reviews.comment_grading: Grades are not that important for PG students. Prof. Bao is a very nice guy, and most of the students got A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Only one take-home final exam, no assignment.
